review.title: Relation Schema Induction using Tensor Factorization with Side Information
review.abstract: Given a set of documents from a specific domain (e.g., medical research journals), how do we automatically identify the schema of relations i.e., type signature of arguments of relations (e.g., undergo (Patient, Surgery)) - a necessary first step towards building a Knowledge Graph (KG) out of the given set of documents? We refer to this problem as Relation Schema Induction (RSI). While Open Information Extraction (OIE) techniques aim at extracting surface level triples of the form (John, underwent, Angioplasty), they don't induce the yet unknown schema of relations themselves. Tensors provide a natural representation for such triples, and factorization of such tensors provide a plausible solution for the RSI problem. To the best of our knowledge, tensor factorization methods have not been used for the RSI problem. We fill this gap and propose Coupled Non-negative Tensor Factorization (CNTF), a tensor factorization method which is able to incorporate additional side information in a principled way for more effective Relation Schema Induction. We report our findings on multiple real-world datasets and demonstrate CNTF's effectiveness over state-of-the-art baselines both in terms of accuracy and speed.
histories: Proceedings of the 2016 Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing, November 2016. Austin, TX

sections.heading: 3 Our Approach: Schema Induction using Coupled Tensor Factorization (SICTF)
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 3.1 Overview
sections.text: SICTF presents the relation diagram induction problem as a coupled factorization of a tensor, together with matrices containing relevant lateral information. The overall architecture of the SICTF system is shown in Figure 1. First, a tensor X-Attias and Cohen is constructed to capture the noun phrase (NP).

sections.heading: 3.2 Side Information
sections.text: We use Hearst patterns (Hearst, 1992), such as "< hypernym > like < NP >," to extract such (NP, hypernym) pairs from the corpus. Please note that neither hypernymes nor NPs are predefined, and they are all extracted from the data through the patterns. Examples of a few such pairs extracted from two different sets of data are shown in Table 2. These extracted tuples are stored in a matrix Wn × h, whose rows and columns correspond to NPs and columns of extracted hypernymes. We define Wij = {1, if NPi belongs to two different sets of data, we are able to detect relativity 0.

sections.heading: 4 Experiments
sections.text: In this section, we evaluate the performance of different methods for the Relation Schema Induction (RSI) task. Specifically, we will address the following questions. • Which method is most effective for the RSI task? (Section 4.3.1) • How important is the additional ancillary information for RSI? (Section 4.3.2) • What is the significance of non-negativity for RSI with tensor factorization? (Section 4.3.3)

sections.heading: 4.1 Experimental Setup
sections.text: Datasets: We used two sets of data for the experiments in this paper, summarized in Table 4. For MEDLINE datasets, we used Stanford CoreNLP (Manning et al., 2014) for coreference resolution and Open IE v4.09 for triple extraction. Triples with noun phrases containing hypernym information were retained. We received the stack overflow triples directly from the authors of (Movshovitz-Attias and Cohen, 2015), which were also prepared using a very similar procedure. In both sets, we use the corpus frequency of triples for the construction of the tensor. Side Information: Seven Hearst Patterns such as "< hypernym > such as < NP >," < NP > or other < hypernym >, "etc., given sets of triples for the construction of the hyperltlt; hyperlt; NP or hyperltlt; < NP > hyperlt; < other than < NP; <

sections.heading: 4.2 Evaluation Protocol
sections.text: In this section, we will describe how the induced schemes of human commentators are presented and how the final accuracies are calculated. In factorizations created by SICTF and other lowered versions of SICTF, we will first select some top relations with the best reconstruction value. The schemes generated for each selected relation k are represented by the matrix disk Rk of the core tensor obtained after factorization (see section 3). From each such matrix, we identify the indices (i, j) with the highest values. The indices i and j select columns of matrix A. Some top NPs from the columns Ai and Aj are presented together with the relation k to the human commentator, who then evaluates whether the tuple relation (Ai, Aj) represents a valid scheme for the relation scale. Examples of a few relation scripts induced by SICF Tinduced are shown in Table 5.

sections.heading: 4.3 Results
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 4.3.1 Effectiveness of SICTF
sections.text: Experimental results comparing the performance of different methods of RSI task in the two datasets are presented in Figure 2 (a). RSI accuracy is calculated based on the evaluation protocol described in Section 4.2. KB-LDA performance for the StackOveflow dataset was taken directly from the (Movshovitz-Attias and Cohen, 2015) paper, we used our implementation of KB-LDA for the MEDLINE dataset. Annotation accuracies of two annotators were averaged to obtain the final accuracy. Figure 2 (a) shows that SICTF exceeds KB-LDA in the RSI task. Please note that the Interannotator Agreement for SICTF exceeds 88% and 97% for MEDLINE and StackOverflow datasets respectively over the average time. This is the main result of the paper.

sections.heading: 4.3.2 Importance of Side Information
sections.text: One of the central hypotheses of our approach is that coupled factorization with additional page information should lead to better relation schema induction. To further evaluate this thesis, we compare the performance of SICTF with its repositioned versions: (1) SICTF (λrel = 0), which corresponds to the setting when no relational information is used, (2) SICTF (λnp = 0), which corresponds to the setting when no ancillary information of any kind is used. Hyperparameters are adjusted separately for the variants of SICTF. Results are presented in the first four lines of Table 6. Therefore, we find that additional coupling through the page information significantly improves the performance of SICTF.

sections.heading: 4.3.3 Importance of Non-Negativity on Relation Schema Induction
sections.text: In the last row of Table 6, we also present a stripped-down version of SICTF, if no ancillary information is used, no non-negativity limitations. Comparing the last two rows of this table, we find that non-negativity limitations over the A matrix and the core tensor R result in a significant performance improvement. We note that the last row in Table 6 corresponds to RESCAL (Nickel et al., 2011) and the fourth row Non-Negative RESCAL (Krompass et al., 2013), two tensor factoring techniques. We also note that none of these tensor factoring techniques has previously been used for the relationship schema induction problem. The reason for this improved performance can be explained by the fact that the lack of a non-negativity limitation leads to an insufficient factoring problem, where the model often overgenerates wrong triples and then compensates them with a more compensated factor.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: Relation Schema Induction (RSI) is an important first step in building a Knowledge Graph (KG) from text corpus of a particular domain. While human domain experts have traditionally prepared a listing of relationships and their schemas, this expert-mediated model presents significant challenges in terms of scalability and coverage. To address these challenges, in this paper we present SICTF, a novel non-negative coupled tensor matrix factorization method for relation schema induction. SICTF is flexible enough to include various types of ancillary information during factorization. By conducting extensive experiments with real-world data sets, we find that SICTF is not only more precise, but also significantly faster (approximately 11.8-fold acceleration) than modern baseline models. As part of future work, we hope to further analyze CNTF credits, apply labels to induced categories, and apply the model to other domains.

sections.heading: Acknowledgement
sections.text: Thanks to the members of MALL Lab, IISc, who read our designs and gave valuable feedback, and we also thank the reviewers for their constructive reviews. This research was partially supported by Bosch Engineering and Business Solutions and Google.

metadata.abstractText: Given a set of documents from a specific domain (e.g., medical research journals), how do we automatically build a Knowledge Graph (KG) for that domain? Automatic identification of relations and their schemas, i.e., type signature of arguments of relations (e.g., undergo(Patient, Surgery)), is an important first step towards this goal. We refer to this problem as Relation Schema Induction (RSI). In this paper, we propose Schema Induction using Coupled Tensor Factorization (SICTF), a novel tensor factorization method for relation schema induction. SICTF factorizes Open Information Extraction (OpenIE) triples extracted from a domain corpus along with additional side information in a principled way to induce relation schemas. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first application of tensor factorization for the RSI problem. Through extensive experiments on multiple real-world datasets, we find that SICTF is not only more accurate than state-of-the-art baselines, but also significantly faster (about 14x faster).
